SEC. 4. Requirement of a regional strategy for disarming the Lord's Resistance Army, as agreed to in the Senate on March 1, 2007, and in the House of Representatives on June 18, 2007. The President must develop and submit a regional strategy to Congress within 180 days to support efforts against the Lord's Resistance Army, protect civilians, eliminate threats, enforce the rule of law, and ensure humanitarian access in affected areas. The strategy should include a plan to protect civilians, eliminate the threat posed by the Lord's Resistance Army, and establish institutions to maintain the rule of law and prevent conflict in the long term. The regional strategy to combat the Lord's Resistance Army includes an interagency framework for diplomatic, economic, intelligence, and military coordination. It also outlines diplomatic engagement with regional mechanisms, evaluation of progress, and fitting within broader policy objectives in the Great Lakes Region. The strategy under this section shall be submitted in unclassified form, with the option to include a classified annex. The President is authorized to provide humanitarian assistance outside Uganda for areas affected by the Lord's Resistance Army, with an appropriation of $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2010. Additionally, assistance for recovery and reconstruction in northern Uganda is also authorized. It is the sense of Congress that the President should support efforts in northern Uganda to assist internally displaced people and returnees, enhance local governance institutions, strengthen civilian police, and improve access to basic services. To address issues in northern Uganda, efforts should focus on improving the justice system, disarming former combatants, and providing programs for psychosocial trauma. Congress recommends future funding for these initiatives. International Development should increase assistance to Uganda for reconstruction in war-affected areas if the government shows commitment to transparency and accountability. This includes establishing mechanisms to manage programs, increasing oversight, and allocating additional funds to local governments. The United States should coordinate with other donor nations to increase contributions for recovery efforts in northern Uganda and ensure transparent use of funds. Congress suggests withholding bilateral assistance to Uganda if the government is not committed to transparent reconstruction in war-affected areas. Assistance for reconciliation and transitional justice in northern Uganda is emphasized in Section 7. The sense of Congress is to support efforts in northern Uganda for transitional justice and reconciliation, including implementing mechanisms outlined in the Agreement on Accountability and Reconciliation. This includes establishing a body to investigate the conflict's history and human rights violations, and a special division of the High Court of Uganda for trials. The High Court of Uganda has a special division to try serious crimes from the conflict, a unit for investigations and prosecutions, a reparations system for victims, and support for transitional justice mechanisms. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2012 for these efforts. The High Court of Uganda has special divisions for serious crimes from the conflict, investigations, prosecutions, reparations for victims, and transitional justice mechanisms. $10,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2012. SEC. 8. REPORT. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within a year of the strategy submission, detailing progress on implementation and evaluating assistance provided. The report should cover actions taken, assistance descriptions, evaluations of bilateral aid to Uganda, and the status of the Peace Recovery program. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within a year of the strategy submission, detailing progress on implementation, evaluations of assistance provided, and the status of the Peace Recovery program in Northern Uganda. The report should also include information on amounts of assistance committed and provided by the Government of Uganda, donor countries, and relevant organizations. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Appropriate committees of Congress: Committee on Appropriations and Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate, Committee on Appropriations and Committee on International Relations of the House of Representatives.

(2) Great Lakes Region: Burundi, Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, southern Sudan, and Uganda.

(3) LRA-affected areas: Territory affected by the Lord's Resistance Army in northern Uganda, southern Sudan, northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and southeastern Central African Republic.
